I really like your videos and would like go give a small pointer. Refrain from saying "Obviously", you may be saying it for emphasis, but to people who may not know much about chemistry it can feel like you are talking down to them.

With youtube videos each video you make may very well be someone's first introduction into advanced chemistry, so what may seem basic to us may not be so obvious to others so clear and concise information should be conveyed where possible without comments that may alienate those new to the subject looking to learn.

I look forward to many more of your videos!

Great job! I always learn so much when I come to your channel!

It's great to see someone doing chemistry where nothing blows up! What you are showing is what chemists really do (well as close as a home lab can get) and I think that's important as it'll help people understand that chemists are all evil super geniuses in the making ;-). I remember one of my undergraduate experiments was to make an optical brightener as used in washing powder. It glowed strongly under UV as was a really good way of finding out who had bad lab techniques - a couple of students were covered in glowing patches.

I'm sure some of the 10 gram yield is precipitated tin (II) chloride and some tin (IV) salts (I guess at least half a gram (probably more) even after washing). Once tin(II) salt precipitates, it is very difficult to get it into solution again. Tin (IV) salts are even worse. There are ways, how to get rid of them:
1) boiling with concentrated HCl, but this is not very comfortable
2) mixing with diluted nitric acid - the tin residue should dissolve and you could separate them, but phenylhydrazine is basic so this would be a problem
3) both tin (II) and tin (IV) salts are soluble in diluted NaOH solutions, you can purify the yield this way (this is the most convenient)
If you plan to use it for skatole synthesis only, the contamination should not be a big problem, but you will not know exact mass of this reactant. I guess it will be possible to eliminate them after skatole synthesis, but I would work with skatole as little as possible. If I were you, I would purify phenylhydrazine before proceeding.
